what_is_a_prompt.description: A prompt is the text or phrase used to tell Midjourney what kind of image you want to generate.
what_is_a_prompt.details: It can be a single word or a complete phrase. The more thought put into the prompt, the more unique and interesting the image can be.

prompting_tips_and_tricks.short_and_simple_prompts: These typically generate the best images. Use clear phrases that describe what you want to see.
prompting_tips_and_tricks.choose_the_right_words: Use specific synonyms to get better results. For example, instead of 'big,' use 'huge' or 'gigantic.'
prompting_tips_and_tricks.be_specific_with_numbers: Use specific numbers like 'three cats' instead of plural words like 'cats.'
prompting_tips_and_tricks.focus_on_what_you_want: Describe what you do want instead of what you don‚Äôt.

prompt_length_and_details.description: Prompts can be simple, even a single word or emoji. Short prompts let Midjourney's default style fill in the gaps. Include specific elements if they are important to you.

areas_to_consider.subject: Who or what (person, animal, character, location, object).
areas_to_consider.medium: In what form (photo, painting, illustration, sculpture, doodle, tapestry).
areas_to_consider.environment: Where (indoors, outdoors, on the moon, underwater, in the city).
areas_to_consider.lighting: What kind (soft, ambient, overcast, neon, studio lights).
areas_to_consider.color: In what shades (vibrant, muted, bright, monochromatic, colorful, black and white, pastel).
areas_to_consider.mood: Feelings to evoke (playful, calm, gloomy, energetic).
areas_to_consider.composition: How is it framed (portrait, headshot, closeup, birds-eye view).

advanced_prompts.image_prompts: Adding images to your prompt influences the style and content of your new creations.
advanced_prompts.parameters: Tools that let you customize how an image is generated, such as adjusting aspect ratios.

additional_help.description: Midjourney has a community that loves problem-solving and helping others.

resources.web: Prompt Craft Room on the web

aspectRatioDefinition.description: Describes the width and height of an image

examples.description: Width is 4 parts, height is 3 parts

aspectRatioDefinition.usage: Determines if the image is wide (landscape) or tall (portrait)

settingAspectRatio.method: Add --ar #:# to the end of your prompt

commonAspectRatios.description: Perfect square, popular for social media profile pictures and posts
Slightly rectangular, used in older TV screens and computer monitors
Common in printed photography and picture frame sizes
Widescreen, standard for HD videos and most modern TVs
Vertical orientation, common for mobile content on social media

additionalTips.tip: Use image dimensions to find the aspect ratio (e.g., 1920x1080 pixels translates to --ar 16:9)
Change a generated image's aspect ratio using pan and zoom out tools or the Web Editor on midjourney.com
--ar cannot contain decimals. Use 139:100 instead of 1.39:1
Some aspect ratios may be slightly changed when upscaling
Older Midjourney versions may not support all aspect ratios
Extremely wide and tall aspect ratios are experimental and may produce unpredictable results

aspect_ratio_guide.importantNote: Aspect ratio is not the same as image dimensions. The final size of your Midjourney images will also depend on the model version and Upscaler you're using.

ImagePrompts.description: Influence the content, composition, and colors of your Midjourney creations by including an image along with your text prompt.

SingleImagePromptWithText.description: Use a single image with a text prompt. Choose an image that resembles what you want and add a text prompt to include details that might not be in the image.
SingleImagePromptWithText.instructions: Describe the entire image you want in your text prompt rather than giving specific instructions for changes.

MultipleImagePromptsWithoutText.description: Use two or more images without any text. Midjourney will blend the images together to create something new.
MultipleImagePromptsWithoutText.instructions: This method focuses mainly on visual cues and works like the Blend command in Discord.

MultipleImagePromptsWithText.description: Pair several images with a text prompt. This combines visual and descriptive guidance, giving Midjourney more to work with for a detailed outcome.
MultipleImagePromptsWithText.instructions: Use the text prompt to add important details that aren't clear from the images.

addingImage.instructions: Click on the image icon in the Imagine bar to open the images panel. Upload new images or select from previously uploaded images. You can select multiple images for your prompt.

options.hover: Hover over the image in the Imagine bar to see more options.
options.changeReferenceType: Change the reference type or remove the image by clicking the X icon.
options.selectImagePrompt: Ensure the image icon is selected to use it as an Image Prompt.
options.multipleReferenceTypes: Hold shift to select multiple reference types.
options.pinImages: Click the lock icon to keep your images pinned to the Imagine bar for use with multiple prompts.

usingInDiscord.instructions: Paste your image URL at the beginning of your text prompt. Separate multiple image URLs with a space. For using multiple images without a text prompt, use the Blend command.
usingInDiscord.validImageURL: Ensure the image URL is valid and the image is hosted online.

imageWeight.description: Control how much your Image Prompt affects the final image. If not set, Midjourney uses the default setting. Higher weights mean a bigger impact on the finished image.

additionalTips.promptRequirements: You need either multiple Image Prompts or a combination of one Image Prompt and a text prompt for your prompts to work.
additionalTips.aspectRatio: Crop your image to match the aspect ratio of your final image for the best results.
additionalTips.parameterCompatibility: Prompts that only use images and no text are not compatible with the --stylize or --weird parameters.

ImagePrompts.gettingStarted: Refer to the Getting Started Guide for more help.

CharacterReference.description: Use the same character in multiple images and scenes using character references.

details.WhatIsCharacterReference: A Character Reference allows you to use a specific character image as a guide for generating new images with the same character. Midjourney analyzes the character's features (like hair color, clothing, or facial traits) and uses these details to recreate the character in new scenes.

AddingImageToPrompt: Click on the image icon in the Imagine bar.
Upload a new image or select from previously uploaded images.
Hover over the image to see more options, such as changing the reference type or removing the image.
Select the person icon to use it as a Character Reference.
To use the image with multiple prompts, click the lock icon to pin it to the Imagine bar.
UsingCharacterReferenceInDiscord: Add the `--cref` parameter to your prompt followed by the image URL.
For multiple images, separate each URL with a space.
Ensure the image URL is valid and accessible online.

BestPractices: Use an image made by Midjourney of a single character for the best results.
Real photos may not yield exact likenesses.
Focus on the text part of your prompt to add specific details not present in the reference image.
Avoid strict instructions; instead, share your creative vision.

CharacterWeight.description: Character weight controls how much detail from the reference image appears in the new image.

options.--cw 100: Includes as much detail as possible (face, hair, clothing).
options.--cw 0: Focuses mainly on the character's face.

AdditionalTips: Combine Character References with Style References and Image Prompts.
Ensure your image file ends in .png, .gif, .webp, .jpg, or .jpeg.
Character References can be used with Midjourney and Niji version 6.

BadPromptExamples: put this man in a cafe
add this man to a cafe setting
GoodPromptExamples: a man with blue hair and gold glasses sitting in a cafe
illustration of a man sitting alone in a cafe

StyleReference.description: Match the look and feel of another image by using style references.

details.WhatIsStyleReference: A way to borrow the 'look' of one image (colors, medium, textures, lighting) and apply it to another image.

UsingStyleReference.AddingImage: Click on the image icon in the Imagine bar to upload or select images. Multiple images can be chosen.
UsingStyleReference.SettingAsStyleReference: Hover over the image in the Imagine bar and ensure the paper clip icon is selected. Hold shift to select multiple reference types.
UsingStyleReference.PinningImages: Click the lock icon to keep images pinned to the Imagine bar for use with multiple prompts.

UsingStyleReferenceInDiscord.Instructions: Add the `--sref` parameter to your prompt followed by the image URL. Separate multiple URLs with a space.
UsingStyleReferenceInDiscord.ImageURL: Ensure the image URL is valid and accessible online.

BestPractices.TextPrompt: Keep it simple and avoid adding style words. Use it to describe your creative vision.
BadPromptExamples: the look of this image but a dog
copy this style and make a bunny
GoodPromptExamples: ballpoint pen sketch of a bunny

StyleWeight.Description: Controls how strongly the style of the reference image influences the new image.

RandomStylesAndSeeds.RandomStyleReferences: Use `--sref random` to let Midjourney select a style from its library at random.
RandomStylesAndSeeds.StyleReferenceSeed: Generated seed can be reused for the same style in future prompts.
RandomStylesAndSeeds.AdjustingInfluence: Use the `--sw` parameter to adjust the influence of the random style.

AdditionalNotes.TextPromptRequirement: A text prompt is required in combination with the Style Reference.
AdditionalNotes.Compatibility: Can be used with Midjourney and Niji Version 6 and combined with Character References and Image Prompts.
AdditionalNotes.AssigningWeights: Individual Style References can be assigned different weights using the format `--sref URL1::2 URL2::1 URL3::1`.

Personalization Overview.Description: Personalization in Midjourney acts as a personal style assistant, helping to create images tailored to your preferences. By liking or ranking images, Midjourney learns your visual tastes and applies this knowledge to generate images that match your style.
Personalization Overview.Niji Personalization: Handled separately on the Niji website

Global Profile.Description: Holds all personalization and style data accumulated before profiles were introduced.
Global Profile.Changes: When you like images from other users on the Explore page

Standard Profiles.Description: Created to focus on specific styles by ranking pairs of images to indicate your preferences.

Moodboard Profiles.Description: Created by selecting inspiring images to set a particular mood or vibe.
Moodboard Profiles.Function: Acts like a vision board for ideas you want to capture.

Actions: View and manage your personalization profiles
Turn on personalization to add your default profile to all prompts
Rank pairs of images until the profile is unlocked
Add images from your computer, URLs, or gallery
Use the 'Copy Code' button to add the profile ID to your Imagine bar or clipboard

Default Profile.Command: Add `--p` to the end of your prompt

Actions: Set a default personalization profile in the settings panel to apply to all future prompts

Personalization Codes.Generation: Profiles generate new codes as you like, rank, and add more image data.
Personalization Codes.Usage: Use the latest code by copying the ID from your profile.

Actions: Rename or delete profiles by hovering over them and using the pencil or trash can buttons
Managing Profiles.Deleted Profiles: Can still be used with previously created codes

Stylize Parameter.Function: Controls the extent of personalization applied to the image.

controller.description: Control, customize, and enhance your images with parameters in Midjourney.

aspect_ratio.description: Change the aspect ratio of your image.

chaos.description: Add variety to your image results.

character_reference.description: Use the same character in multiple images.

no.description: Specify elements you do not want to appear in your generated image.

details.usage: Add `--no` to the end of your prompt in the Imagine bar or in Discord, followed by the list of things you don't want in your image.

bad: still life gouache painting without any fruit
still life gouache painting, please don't add fruit!
good: still life gouache painting --no fruit, apple, pear

important_notes: Midjourney's moderation system reads each word in the `--no` parameter independently. For instance, using `--no modern clothing` might be interpreted as 'no modern' and 'no clothing,' which could accidentally trigger a warning.
It's better to specify the type of clothing you do want in your prompt rather than using `--no`.
details.equivalence: Using the `--no` parameter is equivalent to weighing part of a multi-prompt to '-0.5.' For more detailed information, refer to the article on Multi-Prompts & Weights on Midjourney's documentation.

personalization.description: Create custom image styles with personalized profiles and moodboards.

quality.description: Control the detail and processing time of your generated images.

lower_quality.description: Similar to drawing a quick sketch. Faster results with fewer details. Ideal for quickly trying out many ideas without using much GPU time.

higher_quality.description: Similar to creating a detailed painting. More time and effort, resulting in more textures and details. Can sometimes make things look a bit off if too much detail is added.

default_and_available_options.affects: Only affects the initial image generation, not the later variations or upscales.

details.usage: Add `--q #` to the end of your prompt in the Imagine bar or in Discord, where `#` is the desired quality value.

repeat.description: Generate multiple image sets from a single prompt.

stop.description: Achieve a softer or unique look by stopping the image generation partway.

raw_mode.description: Gain more control over your images with Raw Mode.

standard_mode_vs_raw_mode.standard_mode: The default setting that applies Midjourney's visual aesthetic, adding extra polish and beautification automatically. It's like using a coloring book with outlines and shading tips.
standard_mode_vs_raw_mode.raw_mode: An alternative option that gives you full control over the image, similar to painting on a blank canvas. It sticks closely to your prompt directions, allowing for more photo-realistic images, cinematic scenes, or specific styles without additional styling.

benefits: More control over your prompt directions.
Ideal for creating photo-realistic images that closely match your descriptions without extra styling.
Compatible with Midjourney versions 5.1 and later.

adding_to_prompts.imagine_bar: Add `--style raw` to the end of your prompt.
adding_to_prompts.discord: Add `--style raw` to the end of your prompt.

setting_as_default.imagine_bar: Click the settings button and set your Mode to Raw. This will apply to all future prompts.
setting_as_default.discord: Use the settings command and click `üîß RAW Mode`.

important_notes: Detailed prompts are essential in Raw Mode. If your instructions are unclear or lack details, the resulting image might not be visually appealing.
In earlier Midjourney versions, the `--style` parameter had other functions, which are detailed in the Legacy Features article.

stylize.description: Control the artistic flair in your images.

details.purpose: The `--stylize` parameter acts like a slider that adjusts the level of artistic creativity applied to your image.
details.low_stylize_setting: At a low setting, the image closely follows your prompt with minimal extra flair.
details.high_stylize_setting: At a higher setting, Midjourney has more freedom to interpret your idea, resulting in more artistic and visually interesting images, but they may stray from the exact details of your prompt.
details.range: You can adjust the stylize value between 0 and 1000.
usage: Add `--s #` to the end of your prompt in the Imagine bar.
Set a default stylization for all your images in the settings panel.
Add `--s #` to the end of your prompt in Discord.
Use the settings command and select one of the Stylize preset buttons (e.g., `üñåÔ∏è Stylize med` is the default).

style_reference.description: Match the look and feel of another image.

version.description: Explore and switch between Midjourney's model versions.

video.description: Create a short clip of your image generating in Discord.

weird.description: Make your images quirky and unconventional.

fast_mode.description: Switch your GPU speed to Fast Mode.

image_weight.description: Control the impact of image prompts.

relax_mode.description: Switch your GPU speed to Relax Mode.

turbo_mode.description: Switch your GPU speed to Turbo Mode.

niji.description: Use the model focused on anime and Eastern aesthetics.

stealth_mode.description: Unpublish your image creations on the Midjourney website.

public_mode.description: Publish your image creations on the Midjourney website.

remix_mode.description: Tweak or adjust your prompt text while working on your images.

key_features: Prompt Modification: Edit the prompt associated with an image to generate new variations.
Parameter Adjustment: Add or remove parameters while using Remix Mode. Ensure parameters are compatible to avoid errors.
Variation Options: Offers Subtle and Strong options to control how different the new images are from the original.

web: Click on any image you've created on the Create or Organize page to open it and reveal more options.
Look for the 'Creation Actions' section where you'll find the Remix options. Choose from Subtle or Strong.
If the Remix options are not visible, click 'More options' and add a checkmark next to Remix.
After selecting a Remix option, your original prompt and image will populate in the Imagine bar with the 'remix' label. Edit your prompt and submit it.
Use the Reset Prompt button to revert to the original prompt if needed.
For additional edits, click the 'Editor' button to load the image into Midjourney's Editor, where you can make multiple changes at once (pan, zoom out, remix, and vary region).
usage.discord: The process is similar to the web version, but the specific steps may vary slightly. Ensure you follow the instructions provided in the Discord interface.

details.compatibility: Compatible with various Midjourney versions, but users must ensure that the parameters they adjust are compatible with the selected model version. Incompatible parameters can result in errors.
additional_tips: Experimentation: Users are encouraged to experiment with prompts and parameters to achieve the desired results. Working in small steps and focusing on one part of the image at a time can help in creating detailed and refined images.

Avoiding Common Pitfalls: Users should avoid conversational prompts and be direct in their instructions. For example, instead of saying 'Please change the meadow trail into a beautiful stream,' use 'meadow stream.' This direct approach helps in achieving more accurate results.

text_generation.description: Include words or phrases in your generated images.

details.overview: Midjourney versions 6 and 6.1 allow users to include words or phrases in their generated images by enclosing them in double quotation marks (`" "`). This feature is particularly effective with the standard Latin alphabet, such as English letters.
details.usage: To add text to an image, surround the desired words or phrases with double quotation marks in your prompt. For example, to create an image of a cyberpunk cat with a neon sign that says 'Midjourney,' use the prompt: `"a cyberpunk cat with a neon sign that says 'Midjourney'"`. Single quotes or apostrophes (`' '`) will not work for this purpose.
best_practices: Shorter words or phrases tend to appear more accurately in the images.
Including phrases like 'with the words,' 'text,' or 'written' in your prompt can improve the text's visibility.
If the text does not appear as desired, consider using the `--style raw` option or lowering the Stylize value.
The Editor on the web or the Vary Region feature in Discord can help fix minor issues with the text.

bad: a logo with the company name Boing
put the text 'Hello' in a frame
good: a pastel watercolor landscape with "imagine" written in the clouds
a cartoon drawing of a manual with the words "read the docs" in big text on the pages

details.community_support: For additional help or tips, users can visit the Prompt Craft channel on Discord or the Prompt Craft Room on the web, where the Midjourney community actively assists each other.

usage_tips: Place parameters at the end of your prompt text.
Add a space between your prompt text and the dashes.
Avoid spaces between and right after the dashes.
Do not use commas, periods, or other punctuation marks in your parameters.

incorrect: vibrant California poppies - - ar 2:3 (Extra space between dashes)
vibrant California poppies --ar 2:3, (Using punctuation in parameters)
vibrant California --ar 2:3 poppies (Prompt text after parameters)
